used in medicine

many millions are brought every year to this country
The medicinal leech was however once pretty in the lakes and pools of the north of England

lamenting the scarcity of the animals in the following lines

where they abide

But they have dwindled long by slow decay
still I persevere them
I find
where I may

I have no doubt
you often find these kinds
there is
a small leech the commonest of all called _ Nephelis _
_ Nephelis _ little oval cocoons are so on the under sides of stones in the water and on water plants
I will soon find a few cocoons six
look here under this bit of brick tile
are six
they now contain eggs
as I will show you slitting open the case with my penknife
These gradually change to young leeches , which find their way out of the cocoon through one or other of the two openings at either end
young leeches find their way out of the cocoon through one or other of the two openings at either end
Then there is the horse leech another very similar to it
the horse leech another very similar to it called _ Aulastoma _ "
_ Aulastoma _ means
having " a mouth as wide as a hall ; "
it has no English name
we may give it one
if you like
we call it " the hall-mouthed leech
Its mouth is great stretching
Its mouth can readily take in huge earthworms nearly the size of itself
I once witnessed a curious sight
I put a couple of " hall-mouths " into a glass vessel of water
I introduced also a great fat lob-worm
each leech seized the worm
the one took the head the other the tail
As the worm got gradually swallowed
the two leeches came to very close quarters at last touched
What was to happen
would they twist
they writhe about
break the worm
they so share the " grub " between them
No the one fellow quickly proceeded to swallow his antagonist
I watched him carefully
he succeeded getting down the red lane about an inch of his companion
whether he did not like the taste
whether he had qualms of conscience taking such unfair advantage of a near relation
but I know not
after a few minutes the partly swallowed leech made his appearance again
apparently none the worse for his temporary sojourn in the throat of his companion
This leech may be seen sometimes
damp earth in search of its favorite earthworms
I should mention also
that another worm-devouring leech has lately been found in this country
it is known the name of _ Trocheta _ , called after a French naturalist , Du Trochet
called after a French naturalist
Du Trochet first described it
I dare say
if we look
carefully we shall find it in this neighbourhood

We are now in the fields
the grass is beautifully after the late rain

what a show of May there will be in a fortnight 's time
